Historians tend to describe Ralea's attitude toward Carol as "servile",<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 348</ref> and Ralea himself as Carol's "pocket Socialist"<ref>Seton-Watson, p. 210</ref> or "intellectual trophy".<ref>Boia, p. 131</ref> Ralea himself claimed that the king cultivated his friendship as a likable "communist", though, as Camelia Zavarache argues, there is no secondary proof to attest that Ralea was ever part of Carol's ''[[camarilla]]''.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 189–190</ref> [[Iuliu Maniu]], the PNȚ chief and leader of the semi-clandestine democratic opposition, suggested that Ralea had "not a trace of character" to compliment his intellectual gifts.<ref name="mpîntâlniri"/> At the time, PNȚ activists began collecting evidence that Ralea was not an ethnic Romanian, which meant that he could no longer hold public office under the [[Romanianization]] laws.<ref name="Zavarache, p. 197">Zavarache, p. 197</ref> Ralea himself was involved in the Romanianization campaign: in late 1938, he accepted [[Wilhelm Filderman]]'s proposal for [[Fifth Aliyah|the mass emigration of Romanian Jews]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Aurel Vainer]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20160416040538/https://www.jewishfed.ro/downloads/realitatea/RE442-443.pdf "Contribuția evreimii române la Așezământul Muncii în Ereț Israel"], in ''[[Realitatea Evreiască]]'', Nr. 442–443, January 2015, p. 7</ref>
In December 1938, Ralea became a founding member of Carol's [[One-party state|single party]], the [[National Renaissance Front]] (FRN).<ref>Boia, pp. 133–134</ref> The establishment offered him several honors, including a reprint of his works by the ministry press.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 188–190</ref> In addition to his ministerial appointment, Ralea became Royal Resident, or governor, of [[Ținutul Prut]], a new administrative region incorporating parts of Western Moldavia and [[Bessarabia]].<ref>S. Popescu, p. 35</ref> He was created a Knight 2nd Class of the ''[[Meritul Cultural]]'' Order,<ref>Boia, p. 127</ref> publishing, at Editura Fundațiilor Regale, the volume ''Psihologie și vieață'' ("Psychology and Life").<ref name="gc1025"/> Toward the end of 1938, Ralea moved from his old chair at the University of Iași and took up a similar position at his Bucharest alma mater.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 293, 343, 447; Zavarache, pp. 190, 197</ref> Vianu was the assistant professor, lecturing in specialized aesthetics and literary criticism, and in practice taking over all of Ralea's classes.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 283–284, 447</ref>
Historian [[Lucian Boia]] argues: "Of all the king's dictatorship dignitaries, one may count Mihai Ralea as the most left-wing."<ref name="lb141">Boia, p. 141</ref> In Ralea's own view, the FRN regime was, overall, progressive: "I had inaugurated a corpus of social reforms that were approved by the working class."<ref>Popescu-Cadem, p. 314</ref> As noted in 1945 by political scientist [[Hugh Seton-Watson]], there was a cynical side to Ralea's reform-mindedness: "however much [the average Romanian intellectual] cursed the regime, he was grateful to it for one thing. It stood between him and the great, dirty, primitive, disinherited masses, whose 'Bolshevik' desire for Social Justice threatened his comforts."<ref>Seton-Watson, pp. 211–212</ref> His time in office brought the creation of a workers' leisure service, ''[[Muncă și Voe Bună]]'', together with a Workers' University,<ref name="sdmunivmun">"Necesitatea universităților muncitorești", in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 4/1939, p. 159</ref> a workers' theater, and a hostel for vacationing writers (''Casa Scriitorilor'').<ref>Boia, pp. 140–143, 148</ref> Nepotistic in his selection of a ministerial staff,<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 182, 225</ref> by November 1939 his ministry was able to co-opt PSDR politicians such as [[George Grigorovici]]<ref>Boia, p. 141; Petrescu, p. 458, 459</ref> and [[Stavri Cunescu]].<ref name="sdmunivmun"/><ref name="ițlbfurat">{{ro icon}} Ilarion Țiu, Lavinia Betea, [http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/cum-l-furat-ceausescu-regele-playboy "Cum l-a furat Ceaușescu pe Regele playboy"], in ''Historia'', online edition; retrieved July 1, 2014</ref> He appropriated socialist propaganda, and attracted more or less sizable contributions from various centrists and left-wingers: Sadoveanu, Vianu, Suchianu, Philippide, as well as [[Demostene Botez]], [[Octav Livezeanu]], [[Victor Ion Popa]], [[Gala Galaction]], [[Barbu Lăzăreanu]], and [[Ion Pas]].<ref>Boia, pp. 141–143, 146</ref>
Ralea's mandate was also a crossover of left-wing corporatism and fascism. In June 1938, he even visited Nazi Germany and had a formal meeting with his counterpart, [[Robert Ley]].<ref name="lb141"/><ref name="fmhoria">{{ro icon}} Florin Manolescu, [http://www.viataromaneasca.eu/arhiva/85_via-a-romaneasca-5-6-2013/80_istorie-i-literatura/1492_scriitori-romani-in-exil-vintila-horia-fata-cu-premiul-goncourt.html "Scriitori români în exil. Vintilă Horia față cu Premiul Goncourt"], in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 5-6/2013</ref> His ''Muncă și Voe Bună'' was directly inspired by [[Strength Through Joy]] and the ''[[Opera Nazionale Dopolavoro]]''.<ref name="sdmunivmun"/><ref name="fmhoria"/><ref>Boia, p. 141; Zavarache, p. 189</ref> In 1939, Ralea celebrated [[May Day]] with a large parade of support for Carol II. This was meant to undermine the leftist [[International Workers' Day|Workers' Day]] while showing the success of the FRN's worker [[guild]]s, and was partly inspired by Nazi festivities.<ref name="ițlbfurat"/> Nevertheless, the parade was voluntarily joined by militants of the underground PCdR, who found that it gave them am opportunity for chanting "democratic slogans".<ref name="ițlbfurat"/> In underground PSDR circles, as well as in inside the ministerial structures, rumors spread that Ralea was using secret funds at his discretion to sponsor various PCdR militants, including his schoolmate [[Petre Constantinescu-Iași]]; these stories were partly confirmed by Ralea himself.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 197–200, 201–202</ref>
From March 1939, the premiership had passed to [[Armand Călinescu]], a former PNȚ politician. Ralea was his friend and confidant, and, as he later claimed, tried to keep Călinescu grounded in the face of "mythomaniacal" rumors.<ref name="zoambasador">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/nsemnrile_unui_ambasador "Însemnările unui ambasador"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 6/2001</ref> The FRN regime soon organized a massive clampdown of the Iron Guard. Ralea claimed to have protected Guardsmen employed by the Labor Ministry, and to have negotiated pardons for militants interned at [[Miercurea Ciuc]].<ref>Popescu-Cadem, pp. 313, 314</ref> He obtained one such reprieve for Guardist historian [[P. P. Panaitescu]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 540</ref> Himself a Guard sympathizer, [[Ion Barbu]] later claimed that Ralea was behind his marginalization in academia.<ref>Boia, p. 189; Popescu-Cadem, pp. 332, 342</ref> Ralea was also accused by Pandrea of having done nothing to prevent the arrest of his former ''Dreptatea'' colleague, the anti-Carol PNȚ-ist Madgearu.<ref name="ggglose2"/>
On September 21, 1939, following a spree of extrajudicial killings ordered by government, an [[Iron Guard death squads|Iron Guard death squad]] took its revenge, assassinating Premier Călinescu. Ralea, Andrei, and other former PNȚ-ists preserved their governmental posts as the premiership passed to [[Constantin Argetoianu]], then to [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]].<ref>"Guvern nou", in ''Unirea. Foaie Bisericească'', December 2, 1939, p. 2</ref> Ralea was also given new responsibilities within the FRN structure, becoming president of its regional chapter in [[Ținutul Mării]].<ref>Moldovan, pp. 359, 369–372</ref>
===Downfall and harassment=== [[File:Sala de Consiliu -- Primim & mobilizare.jpg|thumb|250px|Ralea's vote on the [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina|Soviet ultimatum]] and mobilization, registered on Romanian government stationary, alongside those of his cabinet colleagues]] Meanwhile, the outbreak of World War II caught Romania isolated from either the [[Axis Powers]] and the [[Allies of World War II|Western Allies]]. During the [[Battle of France]], the FRN regime itself was divided between partisans of a détente with Germany and Francophiles such as Ralea. As witnessed by the Swiss diplomat [[René de Weck]], Ralea was restating his ''Valori'' ethos at cabinet meetings, in front of Axis representatives, declaring that the Allies stood for "humanistic civilization".<ref name="zoambasador"/> Former PCdR activists still enjoyed access to Ralea, through Constantinescu-Iași. In May 1940, the latter tried to create a bridge of communications between the Labor Minister and the Soviet Union.<ref>Cioroianu, p. 118; Zavarache, pp. 199–201</ref> Various reports on both sides confirm that Ralea was in permanent contact with Soviet diplomats, arranged for him by Constantinescu-Iași and [[Belu Zilber]].<ref>Zavarache, pp. 200–201</ref>
Just a month later, the Soviets issued an ultimatum, demanding that Romania cede Bessarabia. During the deliberations, Ralea voted in favor of Argetoianu's proposal: withdrawing from the region and mobilizing the army on the [[Prut River|Prut]], in preparation of a future defense.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Constantin Argetoianu]], [http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/constantin-argetoianu-ultimatum-mi-s-au-taiat-picioarele "Ultimatum... Mi s-au tăiat picioarele..."], in ''Historia'', June 2014</ref> The subsequent [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina|occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina]] sent Romania into a deep political crisis. The events, and revelations about the existence of a [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Nazi–Soviet agreement]], led Carol to order a final clampdown of the PCdR's remaining Romanian cells. In July, Ralea intervened to rescue a communist friend, the journalist [[George Ivașcu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Pavel Țugui]], [http://www.romlit.ro/george_ivacu_cronicar_de_rzboi_la_ziarul_vremea_1941-1944 "George Ivașcu, cronicar de război, la ziarul ''Vremea'' (1941–1944). I"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 17/2013</ref>
The Romanian crisis was aggravated in August, when the Nazi-inspired [[Second Vienna Award|Vienna arbitration]] stripped her of [[Northern Transylvania]]. The political standstill propelled the Iron Guard, which was Nazi-aligned, into government, and forced Carol into permanent exile. The emerging "[[National Legionary State]]" banned reviews such as ''Viața Românească'',<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 115</ref> and moved to prosecute all former FRN dignitaries. With Panaitescu as the new Rector, the University instituted a Commission for Review, which included Iron Guard sociologist [[Traian Herseni]] and eugenicist [[Iordache Făcăoaru]].<ref>Boia, p. 172; Popescu-Cadem, pp. 314, 315</ref> Of those professors brought before the commission, Ralea was the only one to have his contract terminated without the possibility of transfer.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 540–541. See also Boia, pp. 176, 199; Popescu-Cadem, p. 315</ref> Panaitescu, Herseni and Făcăoaru found that his appointment to Bucharest had been illegal, and dismissed his scientific contributions as having "zero value".<ref>Boia, p. 176; Popescu-Cadem, p. 315. See also Zavarache, p. 197</ref> Ralea and his colleagues were able to defend Vianu, who was openly Jewish, and who was threatened with demotion under the [[Antisemitic laws in Romania|racial purity laws]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 447. See also Boia, pp. 171–173</ref> Withdrawing to Huși, Ralea became the target of surveillance by agents of the [[Siguranța]], who monitored his subversive conversations, including his wager that Guard rule would be short-lived.<ref name="Zavarache, p. 197"/>
In November 1940, the Guard's [[Romanian Police|Police]] chief, [[Ștefan Zăvoianu]], ordered the arrests of several FRN dignitaries, Ralea included. This angered the military ''[[Conducător]]'', [[Ion Antonescu]], who freed Ralea and the others, ordering Zăvoianu to resign.<ref>Gheorghe I. Florescu, "N. Iorga și America", in ''Zargidava. Revistă de Istorie'', Vol. XII, 2013, pp. 168–169</ref> After the [[Legionnaires' rebellion and Bucharest pogrom|clashes of January 1941]], the Iron Guard was ousted, and Antonescu remained unchallenged. Although fascist, the new regime reinstated Ralea to his professorship. Antonescu castigated the Commission for Review as a "shame", and declared Ralea to be "indispensable".<ref>Boia, pp. 198–200</ref> In a companion to [[Romanian philosophy]], published that year, Herseni revised his stance, calling Ralea "a thinker of unquestionable talent", whose sociological work had been "a true revelation."<ref>Herseni, p. 545</ref> Ralea returned to teach at the University where, in addition to Vianu, he had received as his assistant a refugee from Soviet-occupied territory, [[Traian Chelariu]].<ref name="tchmdumbra">{{ro icon}} [[Traian Chelariu]], [[Mircea A. Diaconu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/zilele_i_umbra_mea "Zilele și umbra mea"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 17/2001</ref> Meanwhile, Panaitescu was stripped of his position and briefly imprisoned.<ref>Boia, p. 200</ref>
Still present in public life after the Romania's entry into the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|anti-Soviet war]], Ralea returned to publishing with articles in ''Revista Românǎ''<ref>Boia, p. 243; Straje, p. 586</ref> and the 1942 book ''Înțelesuri'' ("Meanings").<ref name="gc1025"/> Despite being partly recovered by the new regime, and allegedly proposing to Antonescu that they revive together the [[National Socialist Party (Romania)|National Socialist Party]],<ref name="fmhoria"/> Ralea was still under ''Siguranța'' watch, and also spied on by the Police and the German Embassy.<ref>Boia, pp. 200, 237; Zavarache, pp. 203–204</ref> His file contains a denunciation of his entire career and loyalties: he stood accused of having been a "socialist-communist" camouflaged within the PNȚ, of having revived the guilds so as to give the PCdR room for maneuver, and of having sponsored Soviet agents to protect himself in the event of a Soviet invasion.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Stelian Tănase]], [http://www.sferapoliticii.ro/sfera/154/art16-arhiva.php "''Arhivele Sfera Politicii'' – Mihail Ralea"], in ''[[Sfera Politicii]]'', Nr. 154, December 2010</ref>
One ''Siguranța'' record suggests that, in secret, Ralea was hoping to consolidate a left-wing opposition movement against Antonescu during the early months of 1941. More alarmingly for the regime, Ralea had also begun cultivating a revolutionary and pro-Allied youth, through a new magazine called ''Graiul Nostru'' and with British funds.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 202–203</ref> In February, Ralea was subjected to formal interrogations over his contacts with the PCdR under Carol. He defended these, arguing that he had aimed at securing a protective deal between Romania and the Soviets, and that Carol had approved of his effort. The explanation was viewed as plausible by police, and Ralea was allowed to go free.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 198–199</ref> Nevertheless, the file was reopened by August, after revelations that Ralea had cultivated communists since at least the 1930s.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 199–201</ref> In December 1942, Antonescu ordered Ralea's interment at the concentration camp in [[Târgu Jiu]].<ref>Boia, p. 237</ref> He was held there for about three months, to March 1943, and apparently enjoyed a mild detention regime, with visitations.<ref name="zavr203–204">Zavarache, pp. 203–204</ref>
===Antihitlerite Front=== [[File:Gh.Gheorghiu Dej rostindu-și cuvântarea la Congresul Frontului Plugarilor ținut pe Stadionul A.N.E.F. (Mihai Ralea, Petru Groza).jpg|thumb|340px|Ralea (left) and [[Petru Groza]], flanking [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]] as he addresses the [[Ploughmen's Front]] Congress, June 1945]] Ralea's return from camp coincided roughly with the [[Battle of Stalingrad]] and the turn of fortunes on the eastern front. He soon established contacts with the antifascist opposition, repeatedly seeking to set up a Peasantist left and rejoin the PNȚ. Maniu received him and listened to his pleas, but denied him readmission and invited him to create his own coalition from shards of the Renaissance Front, promising him some measure of leniency "for that hour when we shall be evaluating the past mistakes that have thrown this country into dejection."<ref name="mpîntâlniri"/> Their separation remained "unbridgeable";<ref>Zavarache, pp. 196, 204–205</ref> eventually, Ralea reestablished the PSȚ, and attracted into its ranks a Social Democratic dissident faction, led by former PSDR theoretician [[Lothar Rădăceanu]].<ref>Frunză, pp. 116–117, 120; Tismăneanu, p. 83</ref> The two reestablished contacts with the PCdR and other fringe parties: moving between Bucharest and [[Sinaia]], Ralea was involved in trilateral talks between the communists, the [[Ploughmen's Front]] of [[Petru Groza]], and the National Liberal inner faction of [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]], helping to coordinate actions between them.<ref>Undrea, pp. 550, 555</ref> In [[Brașov]], he met with the economist [[Victor Jinga]], whose antifascist and socialist program was reused in later PSȚ propaganda.<ref>Undrea, p. 558</ref> Together with party colleague [[Stanciu Stoian]], he signed the PSȚ's adherence to the PCdR's clandestine "Patriotic Antihitlerite Front".<ref>Cioroianu, p. 132; Frunză, p. 187</ref>
In addition to such underground work, Ralea was notably involved in combating the nationalism and racism of the Antonescu years. He was one of several literary critics who publicly chided a colleague, George Călinescu, for publishing a 1941 treatise which included racialist profiles of Romanian writers,<ref>Boia, pp. 243, 244; {{ro icon}} [[Nicolae Manolescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/g.clinescu_i_detractorii_si "G. Călinescu și detractorii săi"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 34/2013</ref> alongside criticism of Ralea's own anti-nationalism.<ref name="gc973"/> With the 1943 collection of essays, ''Între două lumi'' ("Between Two Worlds", published at [[Cartea Românească]]),<ref name="gc1025"/> Ralea revised his earlier prophecies about the triumph of collectivism.<ref name="pcom193-194">Comarnescu, pp. 193–194</ref>
Evidence of Ralea's participation in subversion was disregarded by government: in June 1943, when the [[German Foreign Ministry]] nominated Ralea as a high-risk target, Antonescu personally replied that this was not the case.<ref name="zavr203–204"/> In November, Ralea applied for a new Chair of Psychology at Bucharest, reserving his old department for Vianu. The review committee, overseen by leftist allies such as Gusti and [[Mircea Florian]], gave him immediate approval for transfer.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 346. See also Zavarache, pp. 205–206</ref> In February of the next year, Ralea and N. Bagdasar rejected the application of [[Constantin Noica]], the traditionalist philosopher, to join the university teaching staff. In his report, Ralea noted that Noica had "an absolute and metaphysical mindset", with no "practical reason", and that he was therefore unsuited for research and teaching.<ref>Popescu-Cadem, p. 276</ref> He also appeared as a defense witness for [[Gheorghe Vlădescu-Răcoasa]], an activist of the underground [[National Popular Party (Romania)|Union of Patriots]].<ref>Zavarache, p. 204</ref> Together with Hudiță and other rival PNȚ-ists, and his friends in Iași academia, Ralea signed to [[Grigore T. Popa]]'s manifesto of the intellectuals, demanding that Antonescu negotiate a separate peace with the Soviets. Reputedly, the document had been stripped of references to the prosecution of FRN and Antonescian officials, leading Maniu to conclude that the signers were "cowardly".<ref name="smhalucin44">{{ro icon}} [[Solomon Marcus]], [http://www.romlit.ro/halucinantul_an_1944 "Halucinantul an 1944"], ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 45/2004</ref>
According to Hudiță, Ralea objected to the Soviets' offer of an armistice as "too soft" on Romania.<ref name="smhalucin44"/> Blocked out of the National Democratic Bloc coalition,<ref name="mpîntâlniri"/><ref>Frunză, p. 120; Zavarache, pp. 204–205</ref> which included the PNȚ, the PSDR, and ultimately the PCdR, Ralea watched from the side as the [[King Michael's Coup|August 23 Coup]] deposed Antonescu and pushed Romania into the anti-Nazi camp. His friend and PSȚ colleague, Grigore Geamănu, was more directly involved, helping PCdR leader [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]] to escape from Târgu Jiu camp and join the other conspirators.<ref>S. Popescu, p. 33</ref> In the PSȚ newspaper, ''Dezrobirea'', Ralea saluted "the full triumph of the ideas and principles for which our foremost activists have been militating uninterruptedly these past six years" (a pedigree which seemingly included Ralea's own activities under King Carol).<ref>Boia, p. 259</ref> He reissued ''Viața Românească'' with a similar statement about "the present triumph of our credo".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 143</ref> Meanwhile, keeping up with his earlier threats, Maniu repeatedly asked for Ralea to be [[Romanian People's Tribunals|indicted for war crimes]].<ref name="ițlbfurat"/>
Ralea played an instrumental part in the gradual installation of communism, and is described by various authors as the prototype "[[fellow traveler]]".<ref name="fmhoria"/><ref>Cioroianu, pp. 154, 290; Stanomir, p. 28</ref> In December 1944, he was announced as the Literary Section Vice President of the [[Romanian Society for Friendship with the Soviet Union]] (ARLUS).<ref>Cioroianu, p. 126, 143</ref> His PSȚ was drawn into the National Democratic Front (FND) coalition, which comprised the PCdR, the Ploughmen's Front, and the Union of Patriots. According to the PCdR, this transformation of the Antihitlerite Front was "a progressive step, befitting the tasks of the people's revolution";<ref>Undrea, p. 561</ref> according to historian [[Adrian Cioroianu]], it was more of opportunistic move on Ralea's part.<ref>Cioroianu, pp. 126–127</ref> In private, Ralea claimed that his alignment with the communists helped him provide for his large family, including former landowners, but his account is viewed as doubtful by Zavarache.<ref name="zavr256">Zavarache, p. 256</ref>
Ralea's Socialist Peasantists were eventually absorbed into the Ploughmen's Front. As noted by Zavarache, Ralea now understood that his influence on political life was "exceedingly minor", aware that Groza himself was merely a communist "puppet"; "consequently, he sought to preserve those offices which could ensure him a comfortable lifestyle".<ref name="zavr225">Zavarache, p. 225</ref> Like the rest of the FND, Ralea participated in the movement to depose the monarchist premier, General [[Nicolae Rădescu]]. Faced with the PCdR's obstructionism, Rădescu approached Ralea with an alternative offer: the Ploughmen's Front was to form a new government with no communist ministers. Ralea divulged this offer to the Soviet envoy, [[Andrey Vyshinsky]].<ref>Cioroianu, pp. 154–155</ref> On February 16, 1945, together with 10 other academics (among them Balmuș, Parhon, Rosetti and Oțetea), he signed a letter of protest, accusing Rădescu of stalling land reform and of undermining the work of the [[Allied Commission]].<ref name="citeroarea">{{ro icon}} Cicerone Ionițoiu, [http://www.romanialibera.ro/aldine/history/asa-a-inceput-teroarea-92991 "Așa a început teroarea"], in ''[[România Liberă]]'', April 21, 2007</ref>
===Arts Minister and ambassador=== [[File:ManifestaciónConGrozaTatarescu.jpg|thumb|340px|Funeral service for the "victims of [[Iuliu Maniu|Maniu]]'s gangs", in November 1945. Front row, from the right: General [[Grigore Vasiliu Rășcanu]], [[Teohari Georgescu]], [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]], Groza, Gheorghiu-Dej, [[Chivu Stoica]], [[Petre Constantinescu-Iași]]. Ralea is visible second row, between Georgescu and Tătărescu]] Bloody clashes ensued in Bucharest, most of them between anticommunists and communist agents.<ref name="citeroarea"/> They signaled a new political crisis, and forced the FND into power. Ralea was made [[Ministry of Culture and National Patrimony|Minister of Arts]] on March 6, 1945, when Groza took the premiership from the deposed General Rădescu.<ref>Cioroianu, pp. 127, 154; Vasile (2010), pp. 71–72; Zavarache, p. 222</ref> In June 1945 Ralea was one of the rapporteurs at the Ploughmen's Front largest-ever General Congress.<ref>Cioroianu, pp. 158–159</ref> On March 6, 1946, he also took over the Ministry of Religious Affairs, replacing the disgraced [[Constantin Burducea]] until August (when Groza himself replaced him in this function).<ref>George Enache, "Strategii de infiltrare și atragere la colaborare a cultelor religioase elaborate de autoritățile procomuniste din România în perioada 1945-1947, cu o privire specială asupra cazului Bisericii Ortodoxe Române", in ''Caietele CNSAS'', Nr. 1/2008, pp. 74, 76</ref>
Ralea became one of several intellectuals who were mobilized to run on the Ploughmen's Front (and FND) list in the [[Romanian general election, 1946|1946 parliamentary election]].<ref>Boia, p. 273; Cioroianu, p. 289</ref> In his capacity as minister, Ralea set in motion the purge of PNȚ-ist functionaries and of artists perceived by the PCdR as pro-fascist.<ref>Catalan, pp. 187–188, 190; Vasile (2010), pp. 131–132</ref> He extended his personal protection to [[Șerban Cioculescu]], who became Iași University professor in 1946 upon Ralea's intervention.<ref>Nastasă (2007), pp. 358–359</ref> Ralea also pursued his projects for workers' education, authorizing the establishment of a workers' theatrical troupe, ''[[Odeon Theatre (Bucharest)|Teatrul Muncitoresc CFR Giulești]]''.<ref>Catalan, pp. 188–190</ref> He also republished his 1930s travel accounts, completed with notes from his trip to [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]], as ''Nord-Sud'' ("North-South").<ref>Constantinescu, pp. 285–291; Vianu, p. 158</ref>
In September 1946, Ralea stepped down from the Ministry of Arts, only to be appointed [[List of Ambassadors from Romania to the United States|Ambassador to the United States]]. Reputedly, he was a last minute replacement for the Union of Patriots' [[Dumitru Bagdasar]]. The latter had fallen severely ill,<ref name="abasclepios">{{ro icon}} [[Alexandra Bellow]], [http://www.revista22.ro/articol-1115.html "Asclepios versus Hades în România (II)"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 755, September 2004</ref> but was also seen as a political liability by the American side—Ralea, as a former monarchist, was preferable.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 222–223</ref> Ralea's own arrival in Washington was delayed by his inclusion on the Romanian delegation to the [[Paris Peace Treaties, 1947|Paris Peace Conference]], and he finally landed on American soil in October.<ref>Deaconescu, p. 28; Zavarache, p. 223</ref> He supported a détente in [[Romania–United States relations|Romanian–American relations]], after [[President of the United States|President]] [[Harry S. Truman]] had refused to recognize the Groza cabinet. In front of American criticism, he played down the electoral fraud of 1946, claiming that it was within the "normal" boundaries, at some 5% of the vote.<ref>Cioroianu, p. 127. See also Zavarache, p. 223</ref>
Ralea was also tasked with undermining the reputation of the anticommunist opposition and with popularizing communism among [[Romanian American]] exiles.<ref>Deaconescu, p. 28; Grigorescu & Ștefan, ''passim''</ref> The anticommunist press responded by calling Ralea "a liaison man" of the [[Politburo]], tasked with planting [[Stalinism]] in America.<ref>Walter Dushnyck, "Stalin's Pan-Slavism in the United States", in ''[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]'', Nr. 30/1948, p. 2</ref> Among expatriate Romanians, Ralea and his legation staff had difficulties convincing [[Maruca Cantacuzino|Maruca]] and [[George Enescu]], but persuaded [[Dimitrie Gusti]] to return to Bucharest.<ref>Grigorescu & Ștefan, pp. 24–25</ref> Ralea also approached the former backers of Carol's regime. He build a connection with the industrialist [[Nicolae Malaxa]], but found vocal adversaries in [[Max Auschnitt]] and [[Richard Franasovici]].<ref>Grigorescu & Ștefan, pp. 25–27</ref>
Going against Soviet policies and his own government, Ralea also sought to obtain American foreign aid, and even political interventions. His persistence in this regard contributed to the relief effort organized by [[Cortlandt V.R. Schuyler|General Schuyler]] in famine-stricken [[Western Moldavia]].<ref name="abasclepios"/> However, the assistance fell below Ralea's expectations, owing to various factors, one of which was American suspicion that Groza was diverting food to relieve the [[Soviet famine of 1946–47|Soviet famine]]; meanwhile, diaspora voices repeatedly argued that Ralea was playing down the scale of famine, and also insinuated that he was embezzling funds.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 224–225</ref> In his reports to Bucharest, Ralea complained that: "America's attitude toward us was oscillating between hostility and ignorance. All doors were closed. [...] We were seen as a Soviet branch office, and people were discouraged from giving us any sort of assistance."<ref>Deaconescu, p. 28</ref> Reportedly, he was shocked by Truman's ignorance of Romanian affairs.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/un_raport_american_despre_romnia_din_1949 "Un raport american despre România din 1949"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 48/2001</ref> Ralea's diplomatic mission was also tainted by his difficult lifestyle, including his noticeable [[hypochondriasis]],<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 207, 267</ref> but also his philandering. Ralea had appointed his mistress as [[cultural attaché]], but she deserted her post and left to Mexico while Ioana Ralea took up residence in the Romanian embassy.<ref>Grigorescu & Ștefan, p. 27; Nastasă (2010), p. 267</ref>
With the looming threat of Soviet-style [[Collectivization in Romania|collectivization]], Ralea informed the Americans that Romanian peasants valued individual property.<ref>Cioroianu, p. 127</ref> Reportedly, during his January 1947 interview with [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[James F. Byrnes]], he pleaded emotionally for Romanians not to be left "behind the [[Iron Curtain]]".<ref>Cioroianu, p. 127; Deaconescu, p. 29; Zavarache, pp. 223–224</ref> He was still the country's ambassador when King [[Michael I of Romania|Michael I]] was forced to abdicate by the PCdR officials and a [[Communist Romania|communized people's republic]] was proclaimed. Nevertheless, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Foreign Minister]] [[Ana Pauker]] greatly reduced his influence in Washington, transferring many of his attributes to a communist diplomat, [[Grigore Preoteasa]].<ref name="zavr225"/> In June, Ralea also became chairman of a Romanian Institute for Foreign Cultural Relations, which was dedicated to the spread of propaganda.<ref>Florin C. Stan, "Relațiile bilaterale România—Israel (1948–1959). O cronologie", in ''Caiete Diplomatice'', Vol. 2, Issue 2, p. 34</ref>
===Communist marginalization and recovery=== A scandal erupted in July 1948, when the Raleas were denied access to the diplomats' beach in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], having been blacklisted as "communists". Ioana Ralea endangered her husband's position by protesting against this qualifier; at home, rumor spread that the couple was planning to defect.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 225–226</ref> Ralea was able to persuade Pauker not to recall him, and even organized a reception in her honor during October 1948;<ref>Zavarache, p. 226</ref> he also organized a communist counter-manifestation upon Michael's arrival to Washington.<ref>{{ro icon}} Marius Ghilezan, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/De-ce-toti-presedintii-Romaniei-s-au-temut-de-Regele-Mihai-I*articleID_26028-articles_details.html "De ce toți președinții României s-au temut de Regele Mihai I?"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 597, October 2011</ref> While still abroad, Ralea had run in the formal [[Romanian legislative election, 1948|election of March 1948]], taking a Fălciu seat in the [[Great National Assembly]].<ref>Boia, pp. 310–311; Zavarache, p. 225</ref> This allowed him to return to a secure position after [[Mihai Magheru]] took over as Ambassador, in late 1949.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 226, 237</ref>
Resuming his scholarly work, Ralea had to refrain from calling himself a "sociologist", as that field of research had been declared "reactionary".<ref>Zamfir ''et al.'', pp. 5, 6</ref> He was again given the position of psychology chair at the University of Bucharest, and was also made a member of the new [[Nicolae Iorga Institute of History|Institute of History and Philosophy]], whose president was Constantinescu-Iași. Ralea was seconded there by [[Constantin Ionescu Gulian]], with whom he did research into the history of Romanian materialist philosophy.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 237–246</ref> He also prepared an [[Anthropology|anthropological]] tract, ''Explicarea omului'' ("Explaining Man"). Translated into the French by [[Eugène Ionesco]],<ref name="apmorală3">{{ro icon}} [[Antonio Patraș]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/PATRASfeb7.html "Pentru o morală a grației (III)"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', February 2007</ref> it was published at [[Presses Universitaires de France]].<ref name="feexpl418">François Evain, "Revue des livres. Mihai Ralea, ''Explication de l'Homme''", in ''Études'', Nr. 6/1950, p. 418</ref> In November 1948, he had been accepted into the [[List of purged members of the Romanian Academy|recently purged]] [[Romanian Academy]], at the same time as Balmuș, [[Raluca Ripan]], [[Grigore Moisil]], [[Ștefan Milcu]], [[Camil Petrescu]], and PCdR historian [[Mihail Roller]].<ref>Boia, pp. 300–302</ref> A contributor to the PCdR daily, ''[[Scînteia]]'', as well as to its youth supplement and its cultural reviews (''Studii'', ''[[Contemporanul]]'', etc.),<ref name="mstr586"/> Ralea also sat on the editorial staff of the Academy Historical Section's trimonthly, ''Buletin Științific'', alongside Roller, [[David Prodan]], and [[Constantin Moisil]].<ref>[[Dan Berindei]], "''Buletin Științific''", in ''Enciclopedia istoriografiei românești'', [[Editura Științifică și Enciclopedică]], Bucharest, 1978, p. 443</ref>
Nevertheless, the Workers' Party (as the PCdR was known after absorbing the PSDR) was collecting evidence incriminating Ralea. In October 1949, taking its cue from Roller and [[Leonte Răutu]], the party press carried notes critical of Ralea and Gulian's research.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 242–247</ref> The following year, Roller suggested that Ralea's introduction to the works of [[Vasile Conta]] was not up to Marxist standards, and also hinted that Ralea held too many offices.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 246–247</ref> The [[Securitate]] secret police opened a file on him, which recorded his criticism of Roller and other "ignoramuses" promoted by the regime; in exchange, the Securitate labeled Ralea "opportunistic" and "a danger to our regime."<ref>Boia, p. 334</ref> From about 1950, his office at the Institute was infiltrated by informants, and probably also [[Covert listening device|bugged]].<ref>Zavarache, p. 239</ref>
Ralea responded to the pressures by presenting his services as an anti-American propagandist, making his first-hand experience in America into an irreplaceable asset; this assignment was inaugurated in January 1951, when Ralea and Gulian published in ''Studii'' a piece addressing the immorality of "[[American imperialism|American imperialists]]".<ref>Zavarache, pp. 247–248</ref> Working under direct Soviet supervision, Ralea took charge of a research project endorsed by the entire Institute: ''Caracterul antiștiințific și antiuman al psihologiei americane'' ("The Anti-Science and Anti-Humanity Nature of American Psychology", published 1954).<ref>Zavarache, pp. 248–249, 251–254</ref> He was again able to rescue Vianu, this time from communist persecution,<ref>Boia, pp. 308–309; Vasile (2010), p. 277</ref> and intervened to save the career of writer [[Costache Olăreanu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Cronicar, [http://www.romlit.ro/act4099 "Actualitatea: Costache Olăreanu par lui-même"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 40/1999</ref> More discreetly, he paid the bills of his former teacher, Rădulescu-Motru, who had been expelled from academia,<ref name="zavr256"/> and rescued from eviction the conductor [[George Georgescu]].<ref>Basiliade, p. 47</ref> However, he could not protect either his brother-in-law Suchianu, who was arrested and held in communist prisons,<ref>Boia, p. 334; Zavarache, p. 226</ref> nor Chelariu, who was sacked and had to work as a rat-catcher.<ref name="tchmdumbra"/> His disciple, [[Psycholinguistics|psycholinguist]] [[Tatiana Slama-Cazacu]], was forced to abandon her doctorate studies because of her political nonconformism.<ref>{{ro icon}} Al. Niculescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/requiem_pentru_o_savant "Requiem pentru o savantă"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 34/2011</ref>
Ralea still had friendly contacts with his former supervisors in Foreign Affairs, though he complained to his peers that Pauker was snubbing him.<ref>Zavarache, p. 243</ref> Pandrea, who had fallen out with the Workers' Party regime and spent time in prison, later alleged that Ralea, "the impenitent servant", cultivated the friendship of communist women, from Pauker to [[Liuba Chișinevschi]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/extraordinarul_petre_pandrea_i "Extraordinarul Petre Pandrea (I)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 23/2005</ref> Ralea witnessed Pauker's 1952 downfall and banishment, and reputedly kept himself informed about her activities through mutual acquaintances.<ref>[[G. Brătescu]], ''Ce-a fost să fie. Notații autobiografice'', [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], Bucharest, 2003, p. 268. {{ISBN|973-50-0425-9}}</ref> His own survival in the post-Pauker era was an unusual feat. According to Pandrea, it was possible only because Ralea was "without scruples", always ready for a "cowardly submission", and a "valet" of Workers' Party potentates such as [[Ion Gheorghe Maurer]].<ref name="ggglose2"/> As a sign that he was still protected by the regime, in February 1953 Ralea was awarded the [[Order of the Star of the Romanian Socialist Republic|Star of the People's Republic]], Second Class.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 251–252</ref> A close bond existed between Ralea and the Workers' Party chief, [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]], who began cultivating his very own intellectual circle after engineering Pauker's downfall.<ref>Tismăneanu, p. 161; Zamfir ''et al.'', p. 6</ref>
The death of [[Joseph Stalin]] in early 1953 signaled a path toward less dogmatism. This initially hurt Ralea: ''Caracterul antiștiințific și antiuman'', now seen as embarrassing, was not given mass circulation.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 254–255</ref> Nevertheless, Ralea supported Gheorghiu-Dej's adoption of a [[National communism in Romania|national communist]] platform, which was presented as an alternative to Soviet control.<ref>Tismăneanu, p. 220</ref> Over the early 1950s, he had grown disgusted and alarmed by the impact of communist policies in education, but still fearful of approaching the topic in his dealings with communist potentates.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 249–250</ref> In 1955, with the relaxation of political pressures, he went public with his criticism, issued as a report to the Workers' Party leadership. It spoke about the poor scientific standards at Romania's universities, and criticized the appointment of political workers as school principals.<ref>Cristian Vasile, "Propaganda and Culture in Romania at the Beginning of the Communist Regime", in [[Vladimir Tismăneanu]] (ed.), ''Stalinism Revisited: The Establishment of Communist Regimes in East-Central Europe''. [[Central European University|CEU Press]], Budapest, 2009, pp. 378–379. {{ISBN|978-963-9776-63-0}}</ref> The report also condemned the Art Ministry for promoting "mediocrities" as cultural inspectors,<ref>Vasile (2010), pp. 127–128</ref> but avoided any proposal for actual liberalization.<ref>Zavarache, p. 254</ref> By 1957, the Romanian school of psychology had been relaunched, and its official publications recommended Ralea as a main reference, but without mentioning ''Caracterul antiștiințific și antiuman''.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 236, 254–255</ref> At the time, some Romanian anticommunist circles also began taking an interest in Ralea, vainly hoping that he would be appointed premier of a [[De-Stalinization in Romania|post-Stalinist Romania]].<ref name="tchmdumbra"/>
===Final years=== [[File:Bucuresti, Romania, Cimitirul Bellu Ortodox (Mormantul lui Mihai Ralea).JPG|thumb|300px|Ralea's grave at [[Bellu cemetery]]]] In 1956, the psychology section became an independent Institute, and Ralea became its chairman.<ref name="Zavarache, p. 255">Zavarache, p. 255</ref> Also that year, Ralea published his historical essay on French politics and culture, ''Cele două Franțe'' ("The Two Frances"). It came out in a 1959 French edition, as ''Les Visages de France'', with a preface by [[Roger Garaudy]].<ref name="adf253">Alex Drace-Francis, ''The Traditions of Invention: Romanian Ethnic and Social Stereotypes in Historical Context'', [[Brill Publishers]], Leiden, 2013, p. 253. {{ISBN|978-90-04-21617-4}}</ref> Ralea was also one of the select few Romanians, most of them trusted figures of the regime, who could reissue selections from their interwar literary contributions, at the specialized state company [[Editura de Stat pentru Literatură și Artă]]. Ralea was one of the first in this series, with the 1957 ''Scrieri din trecut'' ("Writings from the Past).<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/istoria_unei_ediii "Istoria unei ediții"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 8/2007</ref>
Under a similar understanding with the regime, Ralea and other dignitaries could publish accounts of their travels in capitalist countries—in Ralea's case, the 1959 ''În extremul occident'' ("Into the Far West").<ref name="adf253"/> It had comments on the "iron fisted rule" of the [[United Fruit Company|United Fruit]], and gibes at "the putrefied lazy specimens" of "exploiters" in [[Republic of Cuba (1902–59)|pre-communist Cuba]].<ref>Vianu, pp. 158–159</ref> Ralea was nevertheless active in reintegrating culturally some intellectuals who had been imprisoned and [[Rehabilitation (Soviet)|rehabilitated]]: together with one such figure, Constantin I. Botez, he wrote the 1958 ''Istoria psihologiei'' ("History of Psychology").<ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 149; (2010), p. 312</ref> According to memoirist C. D. Zeletin, Ralea and Vianu had a "courageous and noble" stand after the [[Bucharest student movement of 1956|student protest of 1956]]: acting together, they obtained the release from Securitate custody of Dumitru D. Panaitescu, son of the critic [[Perpessicius]].<ref>C. D. Zeletin, "Perpessicius, sau Pentru ca fresca să nu se șteargă (1)", in ''Acolada'', Nr. 12/2014, p. 6</ref>
Ralea and his family lived at a luxurious villa on Washington Street, [[Dorobanți]].<ref>Lazu, pp. 36, 118, 197</ref> In 1961, he had been re-inducted into the literary canon, mentioned in official manuals as one of sixteen critics whose work supported "socialist construction".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/canonul_literar_proletcultist_iii "Canonul literar proletcultist (III)"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 29/2008</ref> Around that time, Ralea and Vianu mounted campaign for Marxist humanism, and were elected to the National Board of [[UNESCO]] (Ralea was its vice president). Their actions were condemned at the time by the exile writer [[Virgil Ierunca]], who described their "solemn agitation" as a new ruse on the part of Gheorghiu-Dej.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Laszlo Alexandru]], [http://193.226.7.140/~laszlo/eleonardo/n18/Laszlo7.htm "Domnul T."], in ''E-Leonardo'', Nr. 18/2012; retrieved July 1, 2014</ref> Ralea was also sent abroad with a dossier on exile writer [[Vintilă Horia]], who had received the [[Prix Goncourt]]. It showed evidence of Horia's support for interwar fascism. Ralea's mission was hampered by revelations about his own compromises with fascism, published in ''[[Le Monde]]'', ''[[Paris-Presse]]'' and the Romanian diaspora press, under such titles as: "Ralea used to [[Roman salute|lift his arm really high]]".<ref name="fmhoria"/> According to later assessments, the Horia affair and Ralea's participation therein were instrumented by the Securitate.<ref name="fmhoria"/><ref>Popescu-Cadem, p. 312; {{ro icon}} [[Alex. Ștefănescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/ultimul_mesaj_al_lui_vintil_horia "Ultimul mesaj al lui Vintilă Horia"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 50/2008; Geo Vasile, [http://www.romlit.ro/vintil_horia_exorcist_al_exilului "Vintilă Horia, exorcist al exilului"], in ''România Literară'', Nr. 30/2012</ref>
Adhering to the official cultural policy, Ralea was making efforts to be admitted into the Workers' Party. His application was politely turned down,<ref>{{ro icon}} Florin Mihai, [http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/cerberul-ceausescu-contra-lui-zaharia-stancu-agentul-sigurantei "Cerberul Ceaușescu contra lui Zaharia Stancu, 'agentul Siguranței'"], in ''Historia'', March 2012</ref> but he was honored with the vice presidency of the Great National Assembly Presidium<ref name="fmhoria"/><ref>Basiliade, pp. 47–48</ref> and a seat on the republican [[State Council of Romania|Council of State]].<ref>Boia, p. 334; S. Popescu, p. 35</ref> In 1962, Ralea was one of the guest speakers at a [[Geneva]] conference on the [[generation gap]], alongside [[Louis Armand]], [[Claude Autant-Lara]], and [[Jean Piaget]].<ref>C. V., "Bibliographie critique. ''La vie et le temps. Les générations dans le monde actuel. Texte des conférences et entretiens des Rencontres internationales de Genève 1962''", in ''Population'', Nr. 3/1964, p. 604</ref> Also that year, he helped with the recovery and reemployment of a former rival, [[Traian Herseni]]. Reportedly, Ralea excused Herseni's Iron Guard affiliation as a careerist move rather than a political crime.<ref>Ornea (1995), p. 188</ref> Together, they published ''Sociologia succesului'' ("The Sociology of Success"); Herseni used the pseudonym ''Traian Hariton''.<ref>Stahl, p. 703; Straje, p. 323; Zamfir ''et al.'', p. 7; Zavarache, p. 255</ref> Despite such interventions, Ralea was publicly shamed by the dissident poet [[Păstorel Teodoreanu]], who nicknamed him the communist "Viceroy", or "Immo-Ralea".<ref>Basiliade, pp. 46–47</ref>
According to his younger colleague George C. Basiliade, Ralea was an "unfulfilled sybarite", whose luxurious lifestyle did not fit his physical frame and his background.<ref>Basiliade, p. 48</ref> A heavy smoker, and prone to culinary excesses, Ralea checked himself in [[Otopeni]] hospital showing symptoms of [[facial nerve paralysis]], with [[hypertension]] and fatigue.<ref>Nastasă (2010), pp. 437–438</ref> Against the advice of his doctors, he decided to attend a UNESCO meeting in [[Copenhagen]]. He died aboard the train, outside [[East Berlin]], on the morning of August 17, 1964.<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 438. See also S. Popescu, p. 35</ref> His body was transported back to Bucharest, and buried at [[Bellu cemetery]].<ref>Gheorghe G. Bezviconi, ''Necropola Capitalei'', [[Nicolae Iorga Institute of History]], Bucharest, 1972, p. 235</ref> Ralea and Herseni had been working on a textbook, ''Introducere în psihologia socială'' ("Companion to Social Psychology"), which only saw print in 1966.<ref>Stahl, pp. 702, 703</ref>
==Sociology of culture==
===Generic traits=== As seen by Zavarache, Ralea was a man of "outstanding intelligence" with an "encyclopedic knowledge, tightly aligned with the rhythms of Western culture."<ref>Zavarache, pp. 187, 189</ref> Ralea's contemporaries left remarks on not just his hyperactivity, but also his neglect of details, and his eclecticism. [[Pompiliu Constantinescu]] remarked of "petulant" Ralea: "Here is a soul who will not stand for the label of specialization!"<ref>Constantinescu, p. 285</ref> In 1926, [[Eugen Lovinescu]] dismissed Ralea as "a fecund ideologue, paradoxical in his association and dissociation of varied and superficial ideals that have happened to have points of contact with Romanian literature."<ref>E. Lovinescu, p. 116</ref> He reads both Ralea and Suchianu as displays of "useless erudition" and "failure of logic".<ref>E. Lovinescu, pp. 117, 119</ref> Completing this verdict, [[Monica Lovinescu]] saw Ralea as "not truly a literary critic", but "a sociologist, a psychologist, a moralist—a moralist with no morals, and yet a moralist".<ref>M. Lovinescu, pp. 483–484</ref> More leniently, [[George Călinescu]] noted that Ralea was an "[[Epicureanism|epicurean]]" of "vivid intelligence", who only chronicled "books that he has enjoyed reading". His free associations of concepts were "very often surprising, quite often admirable".<ref name="gc911"/> Ralea, Călinescu proposes, was Romania's own "little [[Bernard Le Bovier de Fontenelle|Fontenelle]]".<ref name="gc912"/>
After his French sojourn, Ralea infused Poporanism and collectivism with both [[Émile Durkheim|Durkheim]]'s corporatism<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 118. See also Vianu, p. 146; Zavarache, pp. 187–188</ref> and [[Karl Marx|Marx]]'s theory of "[[class consciousness]]".<ref>Ghiață, p. 8</ref> In his earliest work, he also referenced [[Ludwig Gumplowicz]]'s ideas about the [[Conflict theories|fundamental inequality]] of class-based societies. These references helped him build a critique of innate "class solidarity" as presumed by early corporatism, and also of Proudhon's [[Mutualism (economic theory)|mutualist economics]].<ref>Ghiață, pp. 27, 101–102, 144, 147, 149, 152, 162</ref> Despite this collectivist-functionalist outlook, and although he spoke out against [[art for art's sake]], Ralea was adamant that strictly sociological explanations of creativity were doomed to fail. As he put it, all attributes of a writer were "subsidiary to [his] creative originality".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 35</ref>
Ralea reduced [[aestheticism]] and [[social determinism]] to the basic units of "aesthetics" and "ethnicity". As he saw it, an ethnic consciousness was biologically and psychologically necessary: it helped structure perception, giving humans a reference point between the particularity and generality.<ref>Comarnescu, p. 195; Crohmălniceanu, pp. 128–129, 130; E. Lovinescu, pp. 117–119</ref> An artist, Ralea argued in 1925, was "obliged" to address the national society he lived in, "at the present stage in civilization": "If he were human, he would be discarding specificity itself, that is to say the very essence of art, and would fall into science; if he were too specific, too original, he'd stand to lose his means of expression, the point of contact with his public".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 128–129</ref> Ralea believed that the origin of beauty was biological, before being human or social; he also claimed (questionably so, according to art critic [[Petru Comarnescu]]) that traditional society allowed no depiction of ugliness before the arrival of [[Christian art]].<ref>Comarnescu, pp. 195–196</ref>
With this analysis of aesthetic principles, borrowing from [[Henri Bergson]], Ralea toned down his own rationalism and determinism, taking in [[relativism]] and [[Intuition (Bergson)|intuitionism]].<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 118</ref> With his respect for critical intuition, his critique of determinism, and his cosmopolitanism, he came unexpectedly close to the aestheticism of his rival Lovinescu, and, though him, to the "aesthetic autonomism" of [[Titu Maiorescu]].<ref>Constantinescu, pp. 151–152; Ornea (1998), pp. 146–147, 377</ref> Ralea even sketched out his own relativist theory, according to which works of art could have limitless interpretations (or "unforeseen significances"),<ref>Vianu, pp. 148–149</ref> thus unwittingly paralleling, or anticipating, the [[semiotics]] of [[Roland Barthes]].<ref name="agutopia">{{ro icon}} Alex Goldiș, [http://revistacultura.ro/nou/2011/10/adrian-marino-si-utopia-teoriei-literaturii/ "Adrian Marino și utopia teoriei literaturii"], in ''Cultura'', Nr. 343, October 2011</ref> With ''Între două lumi'', he still rejected individualism and subjectivity, but also nuanced his corporatist collectivism. As he noted, militancy in favor of either philosophy had sparked the modern crisis. The solution, Ralea suggested, was for man to rediscover the simple joys of anonymity.<ref name="pcom193-194"/>
===National psychology=== In his essay ''Fenomenul Românesc'' ("The Romanian Phenomenon"), Ralea elaborated on the issue of Romanian [[national psychology]]. He understood this as a natural development of [[Dimitrie Gusti]]'s sociological "science of the nation", but better suited to the topic and more resourceful.<ref>Verdery, pp. 64–66</ref> According to Ralea, Romanians were structurally opposed to mysticism, which could not compliment their true character: "good-natured, even-minded, sharp-witted like all meridional men, [and] extremely lucid."<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 132</ref> The "Romanian soul" was therefore an adaptable and pragmatic entity, mixing a Western propensity for action with a [[Levant]]ine [[fatalism]].<ref>Comarnescu, p. 195; Balázs Trencsényi, "Conceptualizarea caracterului național în tradiția intelectuală românească", in Neumann & Heinen, p. 354</ref> Combating antisemitism, Ralea applied this theory to the issue of [[Ashkenazi Jewish intelligence|European Jewish intelligence]]: quoting [[Werner Sombart]], he deduced that the "rationalist", "progressive" and "utilitarian" essence of Jewishness was socially determined by the Jews' participation in capitalist competition.<ref>[[Andrei Oișteanu]], ''Inventing the Jew. Antisemitic Stereotypes in Romanian and Other Central East-European Cultures'', [[University of Nebraska Press]], Lincoln, 2009, pp. 56, 149. {{ISBN|978-0-8032-2098-0}}</ref>
Although Ralea was personally responsible for establishing a laboratory of [[experimental psychology]] at Iași, he in fact abhorred experimental methods, and preferred to rely on intuition.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 188, 205–206</ref> As a theorist, he gave a humanistic praise to dilettantism and vitality, in the face of philosophical sobriety. He commended [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], the creator of modern [[Romanian humor]], as the voice of lucidity, equating irony with intelligence.<ref>Ornea (1998), p. 367</ref> As noted by Călinescu, Ralea "either intentionally or unconsciously [suggests] that intense flippancy is in fact sobriety".<ref name="gc912"/> Ralea did have his uncertainties about the grounding of his own idea. Caragiale's humor risked making Romanians too accepting of their superficiality: "maybe this genius portraitist of our bourgeoisie has done us a great harm".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/iari_despre_caragiale "Iarăși despre Caragiale"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 16/2006</ref> During his polemic with ''[[Sburătorul]]'' modernism, Ralea attacked the new schools of aesthetics for their artificiality and obsessiveness: "Not one of the truly terrible chapters in life is familiar to [the modernists]. They are not humans, just clowns. [...] Only the demented and children are unilateral. True aesthetics expresses the mature and normal spiritual functions. The alternative is comparative or infantile aesthetics".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 134–135</ref> According to Monica Lovinescu, his critique of "lassitude" and "cowardice" in urban life is "a severe diagnostic of his own disease."<ref>M. Lovinescu, p. 397</ref>
On such grounds, Ralea concluded that Romanian writers "have had no deep spiritual experience", lacking "a comprehension of humanity, of life and death."<ref>Vianu, p. 151</ref> In a notorious socio-critical essay, first published in ''Perspective'', Ralea asked: "Why Did We Not Produce a Novel?". He contended that the grand epic genre, unlike the short story, did not yet suit the Romanian psyche, since it required discipline, anonymity, and a "great moral significance".<ref>Crohmălniceanu, pp. 187–188; Vianu, p. 152</ref> He also postulated a deterministic relationship between the staples of ancestral [[Romanian folklore]] and modern literary choices: in the absence of any ambitious poetic cycles (as found in Western literature), Romanian ballads and ''[[Doina|doine]]'' had naturally mutated into novellas.<ref>Crohmălniceanu, p. 187</ref> In order to mend such a historical disadvantage, he set himself the goal of writing his own novel, but eventually gave up on the idea.<ref>Vianu, pp. 153, 154</ref> At the time of its writing, the essay claimed to count only a few living novelists; by 1935, however, there was already talk of an "inflation of novels".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Marius Chivu]], [http://dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/carte/articol/granta-romania#"Granta de România"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 502, September 2013</ref>
===Conformist Marxism=== In a 1945 interview with writer [[Ion Biberi]], Ralea explained himself as a [[Marxist humanism|Marxist humanist]], influenced by [[André Malraux]] and by unspecified "recent Russian doctrinaires".<ref name="istnm28"/> Expanding on his earlier stances, he understood the [[Socialism (Marxism)|socialist mode of production]] as both desirable and inevitable, to be received with "enthusiasm" by the masses: "[it] provides practically infinite production opportunities, because it excludes personal gain and is no longer dominated by the game of markets, of supply and demand."<ref>Stanomir, pp. 28–29</ref> He conceived of a socialism wherein "man, integrated with communal life, shall have full liberty in his actions".<ref>Zavarache, p. 251</ref> However, according to political scientist [[Ioan Stanomir]], Ralea's discourse is to be read as a "celebration of slavery".<ref>Stanomir, p. 29</ref>
The transformation was accelerated during Ralea's last 15 years of life. Around 1950, Ralea was studying [[Marxist aesthetics]] and [[Marxist literary criticism]], advising young literati, and his colleague Vianu, to do the same.<ref>{{ro icon}} G. Pienescu, [http://www.viataromaneasca.eu/arhiva/70_via-a-romaneasca-1-2-2011/49_note-din-launtru/793_sub-vremi.html "...sub vremi"], in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 1–2/2011</ref> Ralea was also going back on his cosmopolitanism, seeing it as an obstacle to the proper understanding of Romanian society.<ref>Hans-Christian Maner, "Noțiunea de Europa din perspectiva științei istorice românești", in Neumann & Heinen, pp. 257–258</ref> His teaching aid for social psychology was similarly adjusted, introducing chapters on "class psychology", though, as Zavarache argues, these modifications were "surprisingly kept to a minimum".<ref>Zavarache, pp. 240–241</ref> Especially in his reedited ''Scrieri din trecut'', Ralea sought to reconcile Ibrăileanu's [[social Darwinism]] with the official readings of Marxism, as well as with [[Lysenkoism|Michurinism]] and [[Classical conditioning|Pavlovianism]].<ref>Teodora Dumitru, "«Selecție» și «mutație»: două concepte pentru explicarea fenomenului literar", in ''Philologica Jassyensia'', Vol. VII, Issue 2, 2011, pp. 44, 48, 49</ref>
Shaped by political command, ''Caracterul antiștiințific și antiuman'' excoriated American psychologists as tools of the capitalist regime, claiming that capitalism cultivated "force", "triviality", and "sexual debauchery"; Ralea also stated his outrage at the absence of socialized health care in the United States, even though he privately explained that American workers led "satisfactory" lives.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 252–253</ref> To his peers, Ralea complained that "the adoption of a Marxist canon was stifling his ability to interpret", and therefore prevented him from "elaborating valuable papers."<ref>Zavarache, p. 245</ref> He "doubtlessly never imagined that there would be such excess and distortion", and tried to persuade [[Censorship in Communist Romania|communist censors]] not to exaggerate his works' anti-Americanism.<ref>Zavarache, pp. 251, 253</ref>
In ''Explicarea omului'', Vianu notes, Ralea brought up "a fundamental cultural motif, man's urge to create himself ''obstacles'' and consequently break through them with his natural instinct [Vianu's emphasis]."<ref>Vianu, p. 146</ref> According to Ralea, brute ethics existed as "a mechanism for social self-regulation", which helped to distill the "[[Élan vital|vital impulse]]", whereas the accomplished human being would internalize its requirements and verify them against his own rationality.<ref name="apmorală3"/> Overall, Ralea contended that "[[dialectical materialism]] has the complete answer to any fundamental issue regarding social structuring". That answer was in "[[Base and superstructure|superstructures]]", and the references were Marx, [[Friedrich Engels]], [[Vladimir Lenin]], [[Joseph Stalin]], alongside [[Ludwig Klages]] and [[Max Scheler]].<ref name="feexpl418"/> According to philosopher François Evain, Ralea's study failed as a work of [[psychological anthropology]], and merely showed "what superstructures become under Marxist materialism."<ref name="feexpl418"/> Contrarily, critic [[Antonio Patraș]] noted the links between ''Explicarea omului'' (a "brilliant study") and Ralea's earlier contributions to sociology.<ref name="apmorală3"/>
''Sociologia succesului'' was to some extent dependent on Ralea's study of Durkheim's ''[[The Division of Labour in Society|Division of Labor]]'', with its distinction between laws of punishment and laws of restitution (or reward). Ralea maintained that remedial sanctions were a characteristic of modern civilized society, and that the [[social fact]] of "success" was created within that setting.<ref>Herseni, pp. 547–548</ref> However, the work was heavily reliant on [[Marxist sociology]], hypothesizing that socialist societies had perfected new incentives for workers to set collective objectives and succeed at them.<ref>A. Huhnwald, "Bibliographie. Ralea M., Hariton T., ''Sociologia succesului''", in ''Revue Française de Sociologie'', Nr. 2/1964, pp. 219–220</ref> According to psychologist Edgar Krau, Ralea and Herseni gave credibility to "the tenet that the individualistic ethics of capitalism disunites and hurts people"; however, they ignored the reality of communism, which was "not [its] collectivism, but the all-pervading party tuition".<ref>Edgar Krau, ''Social and Economic Management in the Competitive Society'', [[Kluwer Academic Publishers]], Dordrecht, 1998, pp. 36–37. {{ISBN|0-7923-8028-2}}</ref> In Romania, ''Sociologia succesului'' was mainly noted for reintegrating professional (albeit antiquated) references to American psychology and sociology.<ref name="Zavarache, p. 255"/> It marked a fundamental step in the restoration of Romanian sociology, and also allowed Ralea to publish again on a subject which had preoccupied him since 1944.<ref name="cz&al7">Zamfir ''et al.'', p. 7</ref>
==Legacy== Ralea was survived by his only child, daughter Catinca Ralea (1929–1981). In her twenties, she cultivated a literary circle which included poet [[Geo Dumitrescu]].<ref>Basiliade, p. 42</ref> She also had a career in letters, before becoming a [[Radio Romania International]] reporter and [[Romanian Television]] producer.<ref name="acfresh">Alice Caster, "A Short, Fresh Look At Canadian Life", in ''[[The Ottawa Journal]]'', March 18, 1969</ref><ref>Nastasă (2007), p. 157; (2010), pp. 307, 517</ref> In 1969, Catinca provided live coverage of the [[Apollo 11]] mission, including the first [[Moon landing]].<ref>"Un mare comentator sportiv – Ion Ghiţulescu", in ''Buletin de Istoria Presei'', Issues 8–9/2015, p. 12</ref> Additionally, she is remembered for her translations from [[J. D. Salinger]] (which fed Romania's [[counterculture of the 1960s]])<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 307</ref> and [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].<ref>[[Emil Brumaru]], "Crepusculul civil de dimineață. După lungi și dulci discuții...", in ''Suplimentul de Cultură'', Issue 133, June 2007, p. 11; Adina Popescu, "Literatura imaginarului", in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 115, April 2006</ref> With Eugenia Cîncea, she completed a best-selling translation of ''[[Tess of the d'Urbervilles]]'', which had five editions between 1962 and 1982.<ref>Andreea-Mihaela Tamba, "Translating vs. Rewriting during the Romanian Communist Period — Prefaces to Translations of ''Vanity Fair'' and ''Tess of the d'Urbervilles''", in ''Philologica Jassyensia'', Vol. IX, Issue 2, 2013, pp. 267, 268, 269</ref> Against her father's wish,<ref name="acfresh"/> she married in 1958 the actor [[Emanoil Petruț]], who survived her by two years.<ref>{{ro icon}} Loreta Popa, [http://jurnalul.ro/cultura/film/amintiri-din-copilarie-534042.html "Amintiri din copilărie"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', January 30, 2010</ref>
Mihai Ralea's death, coinciding with a spell of liberalization, created unexpected room for maneuver for a younger generation of literary critics and historians, who were anti-sociological, subjectivist, and [[Post-structuralism|post-structuralist]].<ref>Florin Mihăilescu, ''De la proletcultism la postmodernism'', Editura Pontica, Constanța, 2002, pp. 117–118. {{ISBN|973-9224-63-6}}</ref> Nevertheless, some members of this intellectual school, such as [[Adrian Marino]]<ref name="agutopia"/> and [[Matei Călinescu]],<ref>[[Șerban Axinte]], "Modele ale criticii literare postbelice. E. Lovinescu, G. Ibrăileanu, G. Călinescu", in ''Philologica Jassyensia'', Nr. 2/2011, p. 23</ref> continued to draw inspiration from Ralea, having rediscovered his early Bergsonian essays. They were joined in this by [[Alexandru Ivasiuc]], the novelist and Marxist literary theorist.<ref>M. Lovinescu, pp. 395–398</ref> From within the anti-communist movement, Ralea was defended by author [[Nicolae Steinhardt]]. Although a devout Orthodox, Steinhardt treasured the non-believers Ralea and [[Paul Zarifopol]] for their "quick wit".<ref>[[Eugen Simion]], "Nicolae Steinhardt", in ''Caiete Critice'', Issues 1–2/2007, p. 10</ref>
After the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989|1989 Revolution]] and the fall of communism, Ralea's Dobrina estate was transferred by government order to the [[Diocese of Huși|Orthodox Diocese of Huși]], and came to host a convent.<ref>Nastasă (2010), p. 385</ref> His Dorobanți villa, which Catinca Ralea had sold, bears a memorial plaque honoring the sociologist.<ref>Lazu, pp. 197, 325</ref> By Government Act 503/1998, the Romanian Academy Institute of Psychology was renamed ''Mihai Ralea Institute''.<ref>"Guvernul României. Hotărârea nr. 503/1998 privind modificarea denumirii unor unități de cercetare din subordinea Academiei Române", in ''[[Monitorul Oficial]]'', Part I, Nr. 307/1998</ref> The Huși library, also named after Ralea, has been hosting the entire corpus of his works since 2013.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.vrn.ro/biblioteca-husi-are-acum-intreaga-colectie-a-scrierilor-lui-mihai-ralea "Biblioteca Huși are acum întreaga colecție a scrierilor lui Mihai Ralea!"], in ''Vremea Nouă'', November 4, 2013</ref>
Ralea's early sociological writings were republished, as ''Fenomenul Românesc'', in 1997.<ref>Balázs Trencsényi, "Conceptualizarea caracterului național în tradiția intelectuală românească", in Neumann & Heinen, pp. 355, 376</ref> By then, his sociological contribution was being reassessed in various ways, leading to a reissue of his essays as a 1997 volume, put out by [[Constantin Schifirneț]] at [[Editura Albatros]].<ref name="zavr187–188"/> Around 1995, a heated public debate erupted, focusing on the careers of leftist intellectuals such as Ralea, and their supposed acts of self-betrayal. The central question, brought up by researcher [[Marin Nițescu]], was: would they have done better not to publish at all under communism?<ref>Vasile (2010), pp. 21, 297–298</ref> In 2010, a group of sociologists defended Ralea's prestige, noting that "we [Romanians] are inexcusably delaying in recognizing Mihai Ralea's sociological contribution".<ref name="cz&al7"/>

[[File:Misc pollen colorized.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Colorized [[scanning electron microscopy]] (SEM) image of [[pollen]] from a variety of common plants: [[Helianthus annuus|sunflower]], [[Ipomoea purpurea|morning glory]], [[Sildalcea malviflora|hollyhock]], [[Lilium auratum|lily]], [[Oenothera fruticosa|primrose]] and [[Ricinus communis|castor bean]]]] [[File:Rust Mite, Aceria anthocoptes.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Colorized SEM image of a [[Aceria anthocoptes|rust mite]]]]
'''NanoArt''' is a novel [[art]] discipline related to [[science]] and [[technology]]. It depicts natural or synthetic structures with features sized at the [[nanometer]] scale, which are observed by [[electron microscopy|electron]] or [[scanning probe microscopy]] techniques in scientific laboratories. The recorded two or three dimensional images and movies are processed for artistic appeal and presented to the general audience.
One of the aims of NanoArt is to familiarize people with [[nanoscale]] objects and advances in their synthesis and manipulation. NanoArt has been presented at traditional art exhibitions around the world. Besides, online competitions have been launched in the 2000s such as the “NANO” 2003 show at [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] and “Nanomandala”, the 2004 and 2005 installations in New York and Rome by [[Victoria Vesna]] and [[James Gimzewski]],<ref name="r5">{{cite web|title= At the intersection of art and science: NANO|work= Los Angeles County Museum of Art|url=http://www.nisenet.org/catalog/exhibits/nano_-_los_angeles_county_museum_art_exhbition|author1=Vesna, V. |author2=Gimzewski, J. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2011}}</ref> and the regular "Science as Art" section launched at the 2006 Materials Research Society Meeting.<ref>[http://www.mrs.org/science-as-art/ Science as Art]. mrs.org</ref><ref name="Tomczyk2014">{{cite book| last=Tomczyk | first=Michael | title=NanoInnovation: What Every Manager Needs to Know|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xtGRBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA115|date= 2014|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-3-527-32672-3|pages=115–}}</ref>
A characteristic example of nanoart is ''[[A Boy and His Atom]]'', a one-minute [[stop-motion animation|stop-motion animated]] film created in 2012 by [[IBM Research]] from 242 images sized by 45×25 nm, which were recorded with a [[scanning tunneling microscope]]. The movie tells the story of a boy and a wayward atom who meet and become friends. The film was accepted into the Tribeca Online Film Festival and shown at the New York Tech Meet-up and the World Science Festival.
Earlier in 2007 a book ''[[Teeny Ted from Turnip Town]]'' was created at the [[Simon Fraser University]] in Canada using a [[gallium]]-ion beam with a diameter of ~7 nanometers. The book contains 30 [[silicon]]-based pages sized by 0.07×0.10 mm; it was published in 100 copies and has an [[ISBN]] number.
In 2015, [[Jonty Hurwitz]] pioneered a new technique for creating nanosculpture using [[multiphoton lithography]] and [[photogrammetry]]. His work ''Trust'' was prepared in collaboration with [[Karlsruhe Institute of Technology]] and set a [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] as the "Smallest Sculpture of a Human Form".<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/adma.201502382 |author1=Yetisen, A. K. |author2=Coskun, A. F. |author3=England, G. |author4=Cho, S. |author5=Butt, H. |author6=Hurwitz, J. |author7=Kolle, M. |author8=Khademhosseini, A. |author9=Hart, A. J. |author10=Folch, A. |title=Art on the Nanoscale and Beyond|volume =28|issue =9|date=2016|pages =1724–1742|journal=Advanced Materials|display-authors=etal}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Nick Ashton-Hart |image = Nick Ashton-Hart at WSIS+10.jpg |image_size = |caption = Nick Ashton-Hart speaking at [[World Summit on the Information Society#WSIS .2B 10|WSIS + 10]], 2014 |title = Geneva Representative of the [https://www.digitaltrade.network Digital Trade Network (DTN)] }}
'''Nick Ashton-Hart''' is the Geneva Representative of the [https://www.digitaltrade.network Digital Trade Network (DTN)] and [https://iccwbo.uk/pages/itu-engagement represents the ICC United Kingdom] on the UK delegation to the meetings of the [[International Telecommunications Union]]. He has served in various capacities as the representative of the technology sector to the UN and its member-state delegations in Geneva for more than a decade, including with the [[Computer and Communications Industry Association|Computer & Communications Industry Association]] (CCIA). Prior to that he was Senior Director for Participation and Engagement and Director for At-Large<ref>http://blog.icann.org/2009/12/nick-ashton-hart-now-senior-director-participation-and-engagement/</ref> at the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers ([[ICANN]]).
He has been the lead negotiator for the [[European_Conference_of_Postal_and_Telecommunications_Administrations|48 European member-state regional grouping in the ITU]] on various economic issues at ITU meetings from 2011 to the present.
He has been active in international policy development and intergovernmental negotiations in various areas for more than 25 years, from trade policy as a representative of the private sector to the WTO and as an advisor to the [[Unctad|UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD)]], was a Member for the Technical Community<ref>[https://unctad.org/meetings/en/Notification/notification2016d208_en.pdf]</ref> of the [https://unctad.org/en/Pages/CSTD/WGEC-2016-to-2018.aspx Working Group on Enhanced Cooperation on Public Policy Issues Pertaining to the Internet (WGEC) 2016-2018] convened by the UN General Assembly, sustainable unban development (UN [[Habitat II]] Conference, Istanbul, 1996 and preparatory conferences), Intellectual Property (WIPO Standing Committee on Copyright and Related Rights,<ref>[http://www.wipo.int/copyright/en/ Standing Committee on Copyright and Related Rights]</ref> 2001–2014 and the WIPO Standing Committee on the Law of Patents,<ref>[http://www.wipo.int/scp/en/ WIPO Standing Committee on the Law of Patents]</ref> 2008–2014), and Internet Governance (at ICANN).<ref>[http://icannwiki.com/index.php/Nick_Ashton-Hart ICAN wiki: Nick Ashton-Hart]</ref>
He has served as a Director and Managing Director of various organisations, including Executive Director of the International Music Managers Forum (IMMF),<ref>[http://www.immf.com International Music Managers Forum (IMMF)]</ref> the international non-governmental organisation representing the interests of music managers and their clients, the featured artist community.
He began his business career as an [[Artist manager#Music managers|artist manager]] for featured musical artists, such as [[James Brown]]<ref>[http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-retail-stores-not/4655517-1.html]</ref> (in partnership with Frank "Superfrank" Copsidas at Intrigue Music LLc) and [[Heaven 17]]. He retired from artist management in 2004.
He speaks regularly on international public policy issues, especially related to trade policy, including [https://hansard.parliament.uk/html/commons/2018-01-23/PublicBillCommittees testifying as an expert witness] at the [[UK House of Commons]], at the [[World Trade Organisation]]'s meetings on the [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/reser_e/datadigitaleco17_e.htm digital economy]. and [https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/devel_e/progwttt_e.pdf trade and development]. In intellectual property policy he's spoken at events as diverse as Digital Hollywood<ref>http://www.digitalhollywood.com/%231-DHEurope/London-Thursday16A.html</ref> and MusicTank,<ref>http://www.musicweek.com/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=7481</ref> the Transatlantic Consumers Dialogue (TACD),<ref>http://tacd.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=142&Itemid=126</ref><ref>http://tacd.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=106&Itemid=87</ref> organs of government such as the [[Committee on Legal Affairs]] of the [[European Parliament]],<ref>http://www.europarl.europa.eu/comparl/juri/hearings/20060131/ashton_en.pdf</ref> and organs of the United Nations and its specialised agencies, for several years during meetings of the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] on behalf of CCIA.

'''''Out In South London''''' is a weekly arts and culture LGBT radio show broadcast on [[Resonance 104.4FM]] every Tuesday at 6.30pm. The show was devised and is presented by comedian [[Rosie Wilby]].
==History== Out in South London was started by stand up comedian and musician, [[Rosie Wilby]], as a monthly show on [http://www.southcityradio.org/ South City Radio] in Peckham in December 2008. Rosie was inspired by shows like Out This Week on Radio 5 Live in the 1990s, where she once worked as a trainee reporter. The show transferred to Resonance 104.4FM in late 2009 as a weekly half hour show. The show was guest presented for two weeks in May 2012 by journalist and author [[Paul Burston]] who also appeared in the 2011 Christmas special. It is featured as an [[iTunes]] podcast under the category 'philosophy'. In 2013, the show went to a weekly full hour format, going out live each Tuesday between 6.30pm and 7.30pm. In March 2013 Out in South London was a 'community partner' of the [[London Lesbian and Gay Film Festival]].
===Notable Guests=== * [[Leslie Jordan]] American actor and playwright (18 January 2011 and 12 March 2013) * [[Peter Tatchell]], political campaigner (26 April 2011) * [[k.d. lang]] singer songwriter (26 April 2011) * [[Bette Bourne]] (3 February 2010 and 19 March 2013) * [[Erin McKeown]] (5 February 2013) * [[Wallis Bird]] Irish singer songwriter (19 April 2011) * [[Heather Peace]] actress and musician (26 October 2010) * [[Patrick Wolf]] singer songwriter (14 June 2011) * [[Zoe Lyons]] stand up comedian (26 July 2011) * [[Jen Brister]] stand up comedian (15 November 2011) * [[Allegra McEvedy]] chef, broadcaster and writer (17 January 2012) * [[David McAlmont]] vocalist and songwriter (1 February 2011) * [[Ian Shaw (singer)]] singer (9 October 2012) * [[Stella Duffy]] writer and performer (January 2009) * [[Penny Arcade (performer)]] (12 June 2012) * [[Sarah Waters]] novelist (19 October 2010) * [[Paul Burston]] Journalist and author (8 March 2010, 9 April 2013) * [[Julie Bindel]], Journalist and writer (9 April 2013) * [[Amy Lamé]] performer, writer and TV presenter (27 December 2012 and 5 March 2013) * [[Nona Hendryx]] vocalist and musician (20 November 2012) * [[Patty Schemel]] American drummer, formerly of the band Hole (20 November 2012) * [[David Bedella]] American TV and stage actor (3 July 2012) * [[Lea DeLaria]] American comedian, actress, and jazz musician (8 May 2012).
===Reception=== Elisabeth Mahoney in the Guardian described the show as "ambitiously wide-ranging" "a likeable listen" and "..a bright, strong show"<ref name="Radio head: Out in South London">{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Elisabeth|title=Radio head: Out in South London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2010/mar/24/out-in-south-london-resonance-fm?INTCMP=SRCH|publisher=The Guardian Newspaper|accessdate=28 April 2013|date=24 March 2010}}</ref>
